filters¶

dlinputs.filters.batched(data, batchsize=20, combine_tensors=True, partial=True, expand=False)[source]¶

Create batches of the given size.

Parameters:
  • data – iterator
  • batchsize – target batch size
  • tensors – automatically batch lists of ndarrays into ndarrays
  • partial – return partial batches
Returns:

iterator
dlinputs.filters.batchedbuckets(data, batchsize=5, scale=1.8, seqkey='image', batchdim=1)[source]¶

List-batch input samples into similar sized batches.

Parameters:
  • data – iterator of samples
  • batchsize – target batch size
  • scale – spacing of bucket sizes
  • seqkey – input key to use for batching
  • batchdim – input dimension to use for bucketing
Returns:

batches consisting of lists of similar sequence lengths

  • data – iterator
  • n – number of samples to print info for

dlinputs.filters.concat(sources, maxepoch=1)[source]¶

Concatenate multiple sources, usually for test sets.

  • maxepochs – number of epochs (default=1)

dlinputs.filters.curried(f)[source]¶

A decorator for currying functions in the first argument.

dlinputs.filters.decode(data)[source]¶

Automatically decode data items based on key extension.

Known extensions: - png, jpg, jpeg: images - json: JSON - pyd, pickle: Python pickles - mp: Messagepack

dlinputs.filters.diskshuffle(data, bufsize=1000, initial=100, fname=None)[source]¶

Shuffle the data in the stream.

This uses a buffer of size bufsize. Shuffling at startup is less random; this is traded off against yielding samples quickly. Data is buffered on disk in a dbm-style database.

Parameters:
  • data – iterator
  • bufsize – buffer size for shuffling
Returns:

iterator
dlinputs.filters.distort(sample, distortions=[(5.0, 5)], keys=['image'])[source]¶

Apply distortions to images in sample.

:param sample :param distortions: distortion parameters :param keys: fields to distort :returns: distorted sample

dlinputs.filters.encode(data)[source]¶

Automatically encode data items based on key extension.

Known extensions: - png, jpg, jpeg: images - json: JSON - pyd, pickle: Python pickles - mp: Messagepack

dlinputs.filters.grep(source, **kw)[source]¶

Select samples from the source that match given patterns.

Arguments are of the form fieldname=”regex”. If _not=True, samples matching the pattern are rejected.

Parameters:
  • source – iterator
  • kw – fieldname=”regex” entries
Returns:

iterator
dlinputs.filters.info(data, every=0)[source]¶

Print info about samples.

By default only prints the first sample, but with every>0, prints every samples.

Parameters:
  • data – sample iterator
  • every – how often to print information
Returns:

iterator
dlinputs.filters.map(data, error_missing=True, errors_are_fatal=False, **kw)[source]¶

Map the fields in each sample using name=function arguments.

Unmentioned fields are left alone.

Parameters:
  • data – iterator
  • kw – name=function pairs, applying function to each sample field
Returns:

iterator

  • v – object to be indexed
  • i – index
Returns:

v[i] if that succeeds, otherwise v

Merge samples from multiple sources into a single iterator.

  • weights – weights for sampling
Returns:

dlinputs.filters.patched(data, patches, maxpatches=10000)[source]¶

Patch a dataset with another dataset.

Patches are stored in memory; for larger patch sizes, use diskpatched.

Parameters:
  • patches – iterator yielding patch samples
  • maxpatches – maximum number of patches to load
Returns:

iterator
dlinputs.filters.pipeline(source, *args)[source]¶

Write an input pipeline; first argument is source, rest are filters.

dlinputs.filters.ren(data, kw, keep_all=False, keep_meta=True, skip_missing=False, error_missing=True)[source]¶

Rename and select fields using new_name=”old_name” keyword arguments.

Parameters:
  • data – iterator
  • keep_all – keep all fields, even those that haven’t been renamed
  • keep_meta – keep metadata (fields starting with “_”)
  • skip_missing – skip records where not all fields are present
  • kw – new_name=”old_name” rename rules
Returns:

iterator
dlinputs.filters.select(source, **kw)[source]¶

Select samples from the source that match given predicates.

Arguments are of the form fieldname=predicate.

Parameters:
  • source – iterator
  • kw – fieldname=predicate selectors
Returns:

iterator

A sink that shows a grid of images.

  • key – key to be displayed
  • label – label field to be displayed
  • grid – grid size for display
dlinputs.filters.shuffle(data, bufsize=1000, initial=100)[source]¶

Shuffle the data in the stream.

This uses a buffer of size bufsize. Shuffling at startup is less random; this is traded off against yielding samples quickly.

Parameters:

  • bufsize – buffer size for shuffling

iterator
dlinputs.filters.standardize(sample, size, keys=['png'], crop=0, mode='nearest', ralpha=None, rscale=((0.8, 1.0), (0.8, 1.0)), rgamma=None, cgamma=(0.8, 1.2))[source]¶

Standardize images in a sample.

Parameters:
  • sample – sample
  • size – target size
  • keys – keys for images to be distorted
  • crop – whether to crop
  • mode – boundary mode
  • ralpha – random rotation range (no affine if None)
  • rscale – random scale range
  • rgamma – random gamma range (no color distortion if None)
  • cgamma – random color gamma range
Returns:

standardized szmple

  • data – iterator
  • f – function from samples to samples
Returns:

iterator over transformed samples

dlinputs.filters.unique(data, key, rekey=False, skip_missing=False, error=True)[source]¶

Ensure that data is unique in the given key.

  • rekey – if True, use the hash value as the new key
